metadata.title: experiences of social support in Paralympic swimmers: a protocol for a qualitative study 2 Authors

body_text.text: Paralympic swimmers with respect to the personal and professional support available, perceived use 28 of the support network and the influence it has on wellbeing and performance.
A hermeneutic phenomenological study will be undertaken using a subtle-realist paradigmatic view.

A purposive sample of British Paralympic swimmers will be recruited to enable exploration of social 32 support experiences. In-depth semi-structured interviews will explore participants' experiences of 33 being an elite para-athlete, the support network, the social support available and how they perceive 34 it relates to their wellbeing and performance. Strategies including reflexivity and member checking 35 will be utilised to ensure trustworthiness. Data will be analysed following the Framework Method; a 36 seven stage process used for qualitative data analysis.

38 This study has ethical approval (ERN_20-0344) granted by the University of Birmingham. Findings will 39 be published in a peer reviewed journal and disseminated to key stakeholders in elite para-sport to 40 inform support services. Swimming has featured at every Paralympic Games since inception.

[11] Para-swimmers are classified 82 into 3 impairment groups: physical (S1-S10), visual (S11-S13) and intellectual (S14); with a lower 83 number corresponding to a greater impairment and greater impact on performance. This qualitative study and protocol have been informed through contact with elite para-athletes and 245 practitioners working in elite para-sport. Elite para-athletes will contribute to the topic guide content 246 and structure through cognitive interviews. Key stakeholders in elite para-sport and para-swimming 247 may be contacted for their contribution and insight to help aid analysis and interpretation of results.

Participation in the study will 260 be entirely voluntary and no incentives will be offered. Any protocol deviations will be documented.

Lived experiences of social support in Paralympic swimmers.

Firstly, I would like to thank you for participating in this interview. Just a reminder that it will be audio-recorded but all information shared will be kept strictly confidential. You are entitled to stop the interview and the recording at any point or terminate the interview altogether if you wish.

You also have the right not to answer a question if you do not wish to. There are no right or wrong answers. I am interested in your own personal experiences, thoughts and perceptions, with the aim of today being to understand your experiences of being an elite para-athlete and your support network. to the personal and professional support available, perceived use of the support network and the 28 influence it has on wellbeing and performance.
A hermeneutic phenomenological study will be undertaken using a subtle-realist paradigmatic view.

A purposive sample of British Paralympic swimmers will be recruited to enable exploration of social 32 support experiences. In-depth semi-structured interviews will explore participants' experiences of 33 being an elite para-athlete, their support network, the social support available and how they perceive 34 it relates to their wellbeing and performance. Strategies including reflexivity and member checking 35 will be utilised to ensure trustworthiness. Data will be analysed following the Framework Method; a 36 seven stage process used for qualitative data analysis.
38 This study has ethical approval (ERN_20-0344) granted by the University of Birmingham in April 2020.

Phenomenology promotes the recruitment of participants from a homogeneous population who have 165 had experience with the phenomenon, but who vary in characteristics and their personal experience.

[49] Therefore, purposive sampling will be used to identify potential participants based on age, 167 gender, impairment and Paralympic experience, because the will enable the provision of rich, diverse 168 data pertinent to the research objectives of social support experiences.

[50] Athletes will be 169 approached and contacted via email and social media to determine interest in participation. FIGREF0.text: Games is a quadrennial global multi-sport event for athletes with impairments, 71 referred to here as para-athletes.[1-2] Since inception in 1960, the number of para-athletes competing 72 at the Paralympic Games has increased 10-fold, with >4300 participants at Rio 2016.[3] The 73 'Paralympic Movement', credited to the International Paralympic Committee (IPC), has led to an 74 increase in sporting opportunities for individuals with disabilities and raised the profile of elite para-75 sport.[4-6] Para-athletes are classified based on eligible impairments, minimum disability criteria and 76 sport classes,[7] ensuring that the impact of impairment is minimised and that sporting excellence 77 determines the success of an individual or team.[8] The increase in para-sport awareness is concurrent 78 with an increase in Paralympic Sport funding, with UK Sport investing almost £75 million into the Tokyo 79 2020 Paralympics compared to £10 million for the Sydney Games 20 years ago.

FIGREF1.text: Interpretation of the data through noting down impressions and ideas, writing analytic memos and discussions with the research team. Interrogation of theoretical concepts and exploration of connections and relationships between categories. The

FIGREF2.text: 176esteem, informational and tangible support, proposed byRees  and Hardy.[31] The lead researcher 177 (BA) has strong communication skills, competed nationally as a swimmer for 10 years and has 178 experience training alongside elite para-swimmers. The research team also comprised expert 179 qualitative researchers (NH, AR, AS) and a para-sport practitioner (PM). Based on these dimensions of 180 information power, it is estimated that the sample size will be approximately 8 participants.calls will be conducted from the researcher's and participants' homes. Given the current 183 restrictions on contact and social distancing as a result of COVID-19 the ethics committee support the 184 use of an electronic video platform to conduct interviews. 185 Data collection 186 The planned start date for the study is May 2020 and the planned end date is August 2020. Data will 187 be collected via semi-structured interviews conducted by the lead researcher, a female MSc student, 188 enabling participants to give a detailed first-person account of their experiences.[44] One interview 189 will be conducted with each participant via video call between May and July 2020 at a date and time 190 convenient for the participant. This method of online face-to-face interviewing is often more 191 convenient for participants whilst still enabling observation of verbal and non-verbal cues. [52] It has 192 also been suggested that there is little difference in the data quality between online and face-to-face 193 interviews, further supporting the use of video interviews.[53] At least 24 hours prior to participation, 194 informed consent will be obtained for the interview and for audio-recording. As is recommended in 195 phenomenological studies, the interviewer will endeavour to create a relaxed, comfortable 196 environment for the participant and engage them in conversation prior to the interview. This will 197 facilitate the development of rapport and make the participant feel more comfortable and more likely 198 to give a rich account.[54] Prior to the interview the participant will be reminded of the purpose of 199 the research, that participation is voluntary and that they can with suspend the interview at any point. 200 A topic guide (supplementary file 1) informed by existing evidence [31, 37] and conversations with 201 elite para-sport practitioners in Performance Lifestyle and Physiotherapy has been created to guide 202 the interviews. Questions are open-ended and participants will be invited to discuss any concepts or 203 thoughts they feel are relevant. The guide includes introductory questions on sporting background, interviews are estimated to last between 45-60 minutes and will be audio recorded and 210 transcribed verbatim. Cognitive and pilot interviews will be undertaken with approximately two 211 Paralympians from individual sports to assess the understanding and interpretation of the interview 212 questions and refine interview techniques.[55-56] Based on feedback amendments will be to the topic 213 guide if necessary. Field notes will be taken throughout the interviews to provide contextual details 214 and to note non-verbal expressions, aiding data analysis and interpretation. [57-58] A reflexive diary 215 will be used to record the details of the nature and origin of any interpretations which emerge through 216 the interview process; aiding trustworthiness.[45] A copy of the transcript will be emailed to each 217 participant to enable member checking. Each participant will be able to add any further reflections or 218 make alterations, ensuring an accurate representation of their perspectives and experiences, adding 219 to the transparency of the research.lead researcher will be responsible for analysing the interview data because of her experience in 223 competitive swimming and training alongside para-swimmers. In hermeneutic phenomenology, the 224 researchers' biases, assumptions and experiences are essential to data analysis and interpretation, 225 [44-46] supporting the reflexive diary. Participant quotations will be used to illustrate key findings, 226 making the results more credible.[60] Analysis will be carried out immediately after interviews and 227 after approximately 2-3 interviews it will be determined whether the topic guide needs adapting 228 depending on responses to provide more focus. 229 230 The Framework Method (a seven-stage process for qualitative data management and analysis) is an 231 established approach commonly used to analyse qualitative data; hence it is appropriate in examining 232 and understanding lived experience of phenomena. [61] The method highlights the importance 233 involvement of individuals with experience in qualitative research, therefore experienced qualitative 234 researchers will be involved at every stage of analysis (NH, AR, AS). [61] The seven-stage procedure 235 based on that proposed by Gale et al.[61] will be adopted to analyse the data(Figure 1). It is possible 236 that the analysis approach will be subject to change due to the inductive nature of qualitative work 237 and the multiple types of analysis, which involves the immersion of text and initial open coding.

FIGREF3.text: qualitative study and protocol have been informed through contact with elite para-athletes and246   practitioners working in elite para-sport. Elite para-athletes will contribute to the topic guide content 247 and structure through cognitive interviews. Key stakeholders in elite para-sport and para-swimming248 may be contacted for their contribution and insight to help aid analysis and interpretation of results. 249 250 ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION 251 Institutional ethical approval was obtained from the University of Birmingham in April 2020 (ERN_20-252 0344). Participants will sign a consent form and receive a participant information sheet prior to the 253 interview. They will have the right to withdraw from the study prior to the interview and within four 254 weeks after the interview. There are minimal risks associated with this study. In the unlikely event that 255 a participant feels distressed or the interviewer is concerned for the participant's wellbeing, the 256 interview will be suspended and the participant informed of relevant support services. Participant 257 data will be stored confidentially for 10 years on password-protected computers that can only be 258 accessed by the researchers, and in accordance with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the 259 Data Protection Act 2018 and University of Birmingham's research governance frameworks. TABREF1.text: This protocol outlines the methods of a qualitative study which will be the first to explore the lived 116 experiences of Paralympic swimmers and their support network. It is anticipated that the findings 117 from this study will provide a deeper understanding of this phenomenon, enabling better support for 118 Paralympic athletes, ultimately improving wellbeing and maximising performance outcomes. 148 participating in the 'hermeneutic circle' between the whole text and parts of the text.[44-45] This 149 methodology is appropriate for this study as it aims to understand and interpret phenomena from the 150 individual's perspective.[46] This allows an in-depth investigation of the lived experiences of 151 Paralympic swimmers. The methodology was informed by, and the study will be reported in 155 Participants will be para-swimmers who have competed at a Paralympic Games for Great Britain and 156 are actively training and competing. They will have an impairment that complies with the International 157 Paralympic Committee (IPC) classification code.[48] Participants must be able to communicate fluently 158 in English and able and willing to give informed consent. There will be no age limit and both males and 167 Sample size will be informed by information power as proposed by Malterud, Siersma and 168 Guassora.[50] This is a tool used in qualitative interview studies and is based on the concept that the 169 larger the information power of a sample, the fewer participants are needed.[50] The study aim is 170 narrow, there is high sample specificity and the case analysis strategy suggests few participants are 171 required. This study will follow the theoretical framework and four dimensions of social support 181 Data will be collected via semi-structured interviews conducted by the lead researcher, a female MSc 182 student, enabling participants to give a detailed first-person account of their experiences.[44] One 183 interview will be conducted with each participant via Skype between May and July 2020 and will take 184 place at a date and time convenient for the participant. This method of online face-to-face 185 interviewing is often more convenient for participants whilst still enabling observation of verbal and 186 non-verbal cues.[51] It has also been suggested that there is little difference in the data quality 187 between online and face-to-face interviews.[52] At least 24 hours prior to participation, informed 188 consent will be obtained for the interview and for audio-recording. TABREF6.text: Before we start do you have any further questions? How frequently do you have competitions?  Do you go on any training camps? These types of support can be provided by different people. They could include family, close friends, partner, teammates, support staff and coaches. Do you feel there are any benefits to seeing this person?  Are there any negatives associated with seeing this person? Any negative experiences?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Do you access different support/go to different people for support in different situations?  Who else supports you in achieving your performance goals?  To talk about the role and Esteem support is 'the bolstering to a person's sense of competence or self-esteem by other people. Giving an individual positive feedback on his or her skills and abilities or expressing a belief that the person if capable of coping with a stressful event'. Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved?  To determine who provides esteem support to the participant.  To determine how important esteem support is.  To determine in what way esteem support benefits performance and wellbeing.  To determine the situations and factors that influence the seeking of esteem support. 4. Informational support is 'providing the individual with advice or guidance concerning possible solutions to a problem'. Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved?  To determine who provides informational support to the participant.  To determine how important informational support is. For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml 5. Tangible support is 'concrete instrumental assistance in which a person in a stressful situation is given the necessary resources to cope with the stressful event' (eg. Financial assistance, physical help). Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved? How important is this type of support to you?  When do you use this support? Are there times when you use this support more?  Why do you use this support? What effect does it have on your wellbeing? And performance?  What role do your teammates play?  To determine who provides structural support and the members of the social network.  To determine in what context this support is accessed.  To determine how important this support is.ConclusionThat's all the questions, is there anything else you would like to add about your experiences with any support staff or other members of your support network?The interview has now finished. Thank you for participating in this study, I really appreciate your time and input. Is there anything you would like to ask regarding the analysis of the data or the next steps of the process?  Ensure participant does not need signposting towards any wellbeing services, do so if necessary.

TABREF11.text: BA is an MSc by research student at the University of Birmingham and NH, AR and AS 284 are supervisors. PM is an expert in elite para-sport. BA, NH, AR, AS and PM all contributed to the 285 topic. BA drafted the protocol with guidance and feedback from NH, AR and AS. NH, AR, AS and PM 286 reviewed the manuscript and commented where necessary. All authors approved the final protocol. Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml

TABREF15.text: Before we start do you have any further questions?  Can I confirm that you have read and understand the information sheet and signed the consent form?  Are you comfortable?  To ensure full understanding of what is expected of the participant during this interview.  Make sure the participant is comfortable and ready to begin. Introductory Questions 1. Can you tell me a bit about yourself? 2. Can you tell me about your sporting background? 3. Can you tell me about your classification and impairment? 4. Can you tell me about your previous Paralympic Games experiences?  Age, where you come from, studying, job  When did you start? How you became involved? What made you start? Why do you swim? Your achievements?  What classification? What impairment? How does it affect you day to day? Use of any aids or prosthesis.  What Games have you been to? Positives/negatives. Sucesses?  Make participant relax and feel comfortable with talking and opening up.  Build rapport.  To gain an insight into the participant's background and their sporting career. Transition Questions 1. What is your overall experience of being an elite swimmer? 2. What does you daily/weekly training schedule look like? Can you run me through it?  What does being a para-athlete mean to you?  What aspects of being an athlete do you enjoy?  Any challenges with being an elite athlete?  Benefits/positives/negatives  How many times a week do you train? For how long? Any land based training?  How frequently do you have competitions?  Do you go on any training camps?  Start to guide the interview towards experiences of being a Paralympic athlete. For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml  Who goes with you to competitions and training camps in terms of support staff?  What sport/performance based contact do you have outside the pool? What does it involve? For this study we are focusing on social support in elite para swimming. Social support is split into functional support and structural support. There are 4 different types of functional support: emotional, esteem, informational and tangible. Structural support is concerned with your support network and who you talk to and see on a regular basis. These types of support can be provided by different people. They could include family, close friends, partner, teammates, support staff and coaches. Before each question I will define what is meant by each type of support. If you are not clear on what is meant, then please let me know.  Do you have any questions?  If you are unsure at any point regarding the types of support, please ask.  Use the social support definitions sheet provided to guide you if needed.  Inform the participant of the background of the study  Ensure the participant knows they can ask questions if they are unsure. Main Questions 1. To start with, earlier you mentioned X (support staff), could you tell me a bit about their role and the support they give you?  How often do you see this person/use this support?  In what way do they support/help you? In terms of performance? In terms of wellbeing?  Do you feel there are any benefits to seeing this person?  Are there any negatives associated with seeing this person? Any negative experiences?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Do you access different support/go to different people for support in different situations?  Who else supports you in achieving your performance goals?  To talk about the role and support provided by an individual that the participant mentioned earlier.  To determine the providers of support.  To determine the athlete's experiences with support.  Then move on to the next person mentioned by the athlete. 2. Moving onto functional support, emotional support is  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you? For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml defined as 'the ability to turn to others for comfort and security during times of stress, leading the person to feel that he or she is cared for by others'. Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved? participant.  To determine how important emotional support is.  To determine in what way emotional support benefits performance and wellbeing.  To determine the situations and factors that influence the seeking of emotional support. 3. Esteem support is 'the bolstering to a person's sense of competence or self-esteem by other people. Giving an individual positive feedback on his or her skills and abilities or expressing a belief that the person if capable of coping with a stressful event'. Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved?  To determine who provides esteem support to the participant.  To determine how important esteem support is.  To determine in what way esteem support benefits performance and wellbeing.  To determine the situations and factors that influence the seeking of esteem support. 4. Informational support is 'providing the individual with advice or guidance concerning possible solutions to a problem'. Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved?  To determine who provides informational support to the participant.  To determine how important informational support is. To determine in what way informational support benefits performance and wellbeing. For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml 5. Tangible support is 'concrete instrumental assistance in which a person in a stressful situation is given the necessary resources to cope with the stressful event' (eg. Financial assistance, physical help). Is there anyone who provides this type of support to you?  In what way do they provide support?  Can you tell me how important is this form of support to you?  How often do you use this support?  Why do you use/need this support?  In what way does this support benefit your performance? What about wellbeing?  Are there situations where you access this support more? Why is this?  What influence, if any, do other people have on your seeking of this support?  Have you had any negative experiences with this form of support? Can you give an example of this?  Is there any way this support could be improved?  To determine who provides tangible support to the participant.  To determine how important tangible support is.  To determine in what way tangible support benefits performance and wellbeing.  To determine the situations and factors that influence the seeking of tangible support. 6. Structural support is the related to your social network: the diversity of social roles and the frequency of social contact. Is there anyone you talk to or see on a regular basis that supports you?  For example: family, friends, partner, teammates  In what way do they support you?  How important is this type of support to you?  When do you use this support? Are there times when you use this support more?  Why do you use this support? What effect does it have on your wellbeing? And performance?  What role do your teammates play?  To determine who provides structural support and the members of the social network.  To determine in what context this support is accessed.  To determine how important this support is.  To determine how this support benefits participant's performance and wellbeing.That's all the questions, is there anything else you would like to add about your experiences with any support staff or other members of your support network?The interview has now finished. Thank you for participating in this study, I really appreciate your time and input. Is there anything you would like to ask regarding the analysis of the data or the next steps of the process?  Ensure participant does not need signposting towards any wellbeing services, do so if necessary. Ensure the participant is comfortable with what has been discussed.For peer review only -http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/guidelines.xhtml
